ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.
M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported
1=Patient is disoriented:cannot state name, location, date; 2=Patient is oriented to self/name only; 3=Patient is oriented to name and location; 4=Patient is oriented to name, location, date
1=Patient is filthy; 2=Patient is unkempt; 3=Patient is clean but slovenly; 4=Patient is clean and neatly groomed

1=Patient does not express needs; 2=Patient expresses needs, but not in an organized fashion; 3=Patient expresses needs in a simple and organized fashion; 4=Patient expresses needs in an articulate and organized fashion

1=Patient does not keep appointments without prompting; 2=Patient is frequently late or misses appointments; 3=Patient is occasionally late for appointments; 4=Patient is prompt and on time for appointments;– 5 = Non-compliant, Fails to keep any contacts with therapist/doctor or follow up on any plans. Patient’s overall pattern is to not seek treatment at all relevant to his/her needs; 6 = Poor compliance, Only occasionally comes to the scheduled appointments or may call doctor with specific problems but usually does not maintain contact. Patient may deny need for treatment except during crisis periods and discontinue treatment as soon as crisis is over; 7 = Limited compliance, Limited compliance Frequently cancels or misses scheduled appointments about1/2 to 2/3 of the time and may have long  periods of time when s/he is not engaged in treatment; 8 = Partial compliance, Cancels or misses scheduled appointments about 1 of 3x but usually seeks treatment at appropriate times. 9 = Adequate compliance, Adequate compliance Attends most scheduled appointments and is engaged in recommended length and type of treatment but occasionally appointments. for minor reasons such as “feeling too tired”; 10 = Excellent compliance, consistently attends all scheduled appointments for recommended therapy

1=Patient does not tolerate human interactions and isolates self; 2=Patient meets only with family members, 1-2 is friends, or hospital staff; 3=Patient interacts with family members, friends and acquaintances, and hospital staff; 4=Patient interacts with family, friends, and acquaintances and meets new
people

1=Patient does not leave his/her own room or house except with prompting from friends or staff; 2=Patient leaves his/her own room or house but only goes to a place or activity that he/she knows well; 3 = Patient leaves his/her own room or house and goes to unfamiliar places to take care of needed errands or can leave the ward and explore grounds; 4=Patient goes spontaneously to new places for social events as well as tasks
or errands

1=Patient does not participate in volunteer program, work program, day
treatment, or hospital milieu program; 2=Patient participates in day treatment or hospital milieu program; 3=Patient participates in day treatment and/or school, or a volunteer or work program at least 6 hours/week; 4=Patient participates in school, volunteer work, or works at least 20 hours/week

1=Patient does not organize or participate in leisure time activities;
2=Patient participates in leisure time activities only if they are organized by someone else; 3=Patient organizes and participates in at least one leisure time activity per week; 4=Patient organizes and participates in at least three leisure time activities per week

1=Patient does not handle his/her own financial affairs in any manner; 2=Patient budgets his/her own funds with the help of a conservator/guardian; 3=Patient budgets his/her own funds but frequently has problems; 4=Patient budgets his/her own funds without problems

1=Patient does not identify or formulate realistic short-term plans; 2=Patient can identify but cannot formulate realistic short-term plans; 3=Patient can identify and realistically formulate short-term plans but needs assistance in carrying them out; 4=Patient can identify and formulate short-term plans and can carry them out independently

1=Patient cannot live independently or semi-independently and lives in a setting
with 24-hour supervision, such as a lock-intensive inpatient ward, long-term
residential treatment program, or in seclusion; 2=Patient lives only with family members or a private custodian  or is currently hospitalized in a research or open ward; 3=Patient lives in a board-and-care or transitional living program; 4=Patient lives independently in an apartment or home with or without
roommates

1=Patient does not understand that he/she is psychiatrically ill; 2=Patient identifies symptoms of his/her own illness; 3=Patient identifies stressors that exacerbate his/her own illness; 4=Patient identifies his/her own symptoms and stressors, and devises coping strategies to deal with stressors

1=Patient does not organize his/her own sleep patterns in any way and is up at
all hours of the day and night; 2=Patient follows a reasonable sleep schedule only with the assistance of others and otherwise would wake-sleep at idiosyncratic times; 3=Patient follows a reasonable a sleep-wake cycle but takes frequent daytime naps; 4=Patient follows a regular sleep-wake pattern which he/she can control without the assistance of others

1=Patient does not answer a simple question coherently and logically; 2=Patient answers a simple question but only with a yes/no response; 3=Patient answers a simple question logically and coherently with more than a yes/no response; 4=Patient answers an open-ended question coherently and logically

1=Patient is severely impaired and cannot function without the assistance of a highly structured environment; 2=Patient is moderately impaired, but can function with a great deal of structure and support from family or supportive institutions; 3=Patient is fairly impaired, but can live and function fairly autonomously with some assistance from family, friends, or other agencies; 4=Patient can live independently, organize time and finances, and has friends and a social life

ElementDescription: Scale of Functioning Mean Total Score

Notes: Study Site
0=Baseline; 1=In Treatment; 2=In Follow-up
1=Long-Acting Injectable Risperidone Microspheres; 2=Second Generation Oral Antipsychotic Medication

-1.5 = Pre-Screening; -1 = Screening; 0 = Baseline; ## = Visit ## (from 1 to 10); Whole numbers = standard monthly visits; #.001 - #.009 = Unscheduled; #.1 = End of Phase 1; #.2 = End of Phase 2; #.3 = End of Phase 3; #.4 = End of Open Choice Phase; #.5 = End of Study; #.6 = Genetic Analysis; 1000=all visits
